lines.text: It's for god to punish the wicked.
Why should god have all the satisfaction?
Joseph, what have you heard?
Been sick. She's up now. With child. Seven month.
And how is Edgar taken that?
He's waiting to the colour of its eyes.

[at Cathy's grave]
Catherine Earnshaw, I say one prayer. May you not rest while I am living.
What'll you do? Make him work?
Aye. But no more than others. We lost a son, didn't we. Now, thanks be to god, we have another. He can be a brother to them.
No doubt he is already.
Nobody can marry Heathcliff. I mean, he's a wild animal.
Nellie, I don't just love Heathcliff, I am Heathcliff. All my thoughts, all my actions, are for him. He's my only reason for living.

[to Cathy]
I've been through hell for you. And if you think it's only me that's going to suffer, then you'd better think again.
When I'm dead, I think I'll come and haunt you.
We'll call him Heathcliff, after our first son.

[voice over]
Despite Cathy's increasing affection for Heathcliff, I could see from the start that his presence bred ill-feeling in the family.

[voice over]
And so, I tended the ailing master, while Cathy and Heathcliff, promising, it seemed, to grow up rude as savages, became more reckless every day. At this time they seemed to need for nothing but each other, so deep and close was their friendship.
I swear never to leave you.
Or this place.
Or this place. Unless you turn against me.
And I swear always to be your friend, and to love no other as you as long as I live. May we both be buried alive under the black rocks of Penistone Crag if we ever break this vow. Now kiss me.
Joseph! Now that I'm back, Heathcliff will have to work for his keep if he wants to stay here.Treat him like the others. Work him just as hard. And, Joseph, no favours. Father's dead now.
Three years you've been away, and you've never even thought of me.
A little more than you have thought of me.
You're cruel.
I've fought through a bitter life since I last heard your voice. And you must forgive me, but I struggled only for you.
Why did you come back?
To settle up with Hindley.
And maybe Edgar too.
Why do you hate Edgar?
Because he married you.

[to Isabella]
Heathcliff, kind? He'd crush you like a sparrow's egg.
Oh Heathcliff. Oh, sweet, precious. Oh, darling.
Do you fancy a tumble, then?
What's that?
Do you want it here or in the bed?
Oh!
[slaps him in the face]
You beast!
If you're not out of this house in three minutes, I intend to throw you out.
Edgar, you're not worth the trouble of knocking down.
All right, Nellie, get the men.
If you can't throw him out yourself, apologize, or take a beating.
